what if you run `./gradlew clean connectedAndroidTest` from the command line
could be android studio smoking crack again
what is it connectedAndroidTest ?
hate this stupid shit from android studio (((
why it smoking crack sometimes((
no, clean is useless
connectedAndroidTest is the gradle command that runs instrumentation tests (that includes espresso) from the command line.
if that fails, you probably have something wrong in your gradle files
if that works and it still doesn’t work in AS, then you’ll need to clean cache, restart, hope and pray to get the thing fixed.
hm
Do you know where ActivityTestRule is located ?
May be I forgot to include some dependency, huh?
what’s your gradle file
can you share it
I’m interested in dependencies and the android bit
wow lol
I have solved the problem
The problem was that my Test classes was located in folder 'test', but should be in folder 'androidTest'

So i’ve recently just dived into Dagger 2, and one question I’ve got is, so lets say I have 2 modules pinned into one component, so inside one of my module i have provideContext method, and my second module has providesDroneDiscovery method, which returns DroneDiscovery object, can my DroneDiscovery just do @Inject and access to the context ?
<@U18E0PY49>: yep pretty much, you can get dependencies from any module belonging to the component you're injecting
Dagger couldn’t get any better, can it ? :smile:
it's quite nice. i have no idea why i had to work on a project that uses it before i understood it
It took me 4 days to understand the very base of it lol
when i started on the docs on an indie project, i felt like i needed to deeply understand how to architect my app around it
but it turns out you just need one component with one module to start, and you're already winning

text: Ah. Okay. So, you just need to remove the provides method for DroneDiscovery and all should be fine
You still need to add the injected constructor to `DroneDiscovery` though
Problem is that you were providing the DroneDiscovery yourself, so dagger will not perform any injection inside it
But how does it inject the context then ?
<@U1HM4MPLJ>: cause it still seems to be crashing
Since dagger will be providing the DroneDiscovery itself, it will inject all the injectable fields before supplying it to your activity
wait did you mean inject an empty constructor like this
<@U18E0PY49|devmatt> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/devmatt/F1SABC7B4/-.java|Untitled>
Yes
and then I don’t need provider ?
Yes
Hmm
this works but it doesn’t make sense for me
in a one way
How come it can inject the Context ?
DroneDiscovery is literally compononentless
well not componontless, i just can’t pick the right word for what i mean :smile:

Normally, Dagger discovers all classes annotated with `@Inject` and will perform all necessary injections for the `@inject`able fields. You need to to the `((DroneApplication) getApplication).inject(this)` bit because the activity instance is not provided by Dagger, hence you need to ask Dagger explicitly
You can look through the generated codes to see how it does it, if you are really curious :slightly_smiling_face:
Oh
So I’m just able to do this because I injected into my application ?
Yea. #magic :grinning:
But isn’t that kinda bad in a one way tho ? :smile:
Actually nevermind, thanks for the injecting help ! :smile:
dagger has several different ways of resolving dependencies, i haven't actually used that technique of annotating the constructor
which is also probably contributing to the weird learning curve
annotating the constructor can get rid of a lot of unnecessary clutter in your modules
I agree. But you'll start to really enjoy every bit of it once you master it
